docs.lead_paragraph: Fresh off a Senate vote to overhaul financial regulations, the Obama administration on Friday immediately began trying to influence the process for combining the Senate and House bills, pressing for tough provisions in the face of a final onslaught of Wall Street lobbying, The New York Times's Sewell Chan and David M. Herszenhorn report from Washington.

headline.main: White House Moves to Shape the Financial Bill

docs.abstract: The Obama administration has immediately begun trying to influence the process for combining the Senate and House bills, pressing for tough provisions in the face of a final onslaught of Wall Street lobbying.
docs.snippet: The Obama administration has immediately begun trying to influence the process for combining the Senate and House bills, pressing for tough provisions in the face of a final onslaught of Wall Street lobbying.

docs.lead_paragraph: I talked to Steven Hayward this week, a sympathetic biographer of Ronald Reagan, about the similarities and differences between the beginnings of the Reagan and Obama administrations. Mr. Hayward emphasized that they both came into office with a clear plan for making major, long-term changes to the economy.
docs.abstract: A Reagan biographer talks about similarities and differences.
docs.snippet: A Reagan biographer talks about similarities and differences.

docs.lead_paragraph: Here are three further thoughts on deficit-cutting, inspired by yesterday's experiment in budget simulations.

Can concern about an ordinary body flaw like misaligned teeth be a sign of a serious psychiatric disorder? That's the question explored by Dr. Katharine A. Phillips, a professor of psychiatry at Brown Medical School. Dr. Phillips recently joined the Consults blog to answer readers' questions about body dysmorphic disorder, a troublesome condition in which people become so obsessed with perceived body defects that they refuse to leave the house or socialize.
docs.abstract: Can a minor body flaw lead to a serious psychiatric problem? Dr. Katharine Phillips of Brown Medical School explores the strange world of body dysmorphic disorder.
docs.snippet: Can a minor body flaw lead to a serious psychiatric problem? Dr. Katharine Phillips of Brown Medical School explores the strange world of body dysmorphic disorder.

docs.lead_paragraph: John Ameroso has been showing New Yorkers how to grow what they eat since 1976 as an extension agent for the city. He is answering questions on growing food.

headline.main: Q. and A. With John Ameroso

docs.abstract: John Ameroso is answering questions on how to grow food
docs.snippet: John Ameroso is answering questions on how to grow food

headline.main: Do Insurers Have to Pay for Colonoscopy Now?

docs.abstract: New insurance plans will have to cover this procedure and others recommended by the US Preventive Services Task Force -- but older insurance plans will not.
docs.snippet: New insurance plans will have to cover this procedure and others recommended by the US Preventive Services Task Force -- but older insurance plans will not.

headline.main: Finding Profit From Investing in Workers

docs.abstract: A six-year study finds that offering pay incentives and health benefits to low-level workers, and listening to their suggestions, can benefit the bottom line.
docs.snippet: A six-year study finds that offering pay incentives and health benefits to low-level workers, and listening to their suggestions, can benefit the bottom line.

docs.lead_paragraph: Accretive Health saw its shares jump 12 percent in its market debut Thursday, after the hospital business services provider priced a smaller initial public offering below the expected price range.

headline.main: Accretive Health Rises 12 Percent in Debut

docs.abstract: Accretive Health saw its shares pop 12 percent in its market debut Thursday, after the hospital business services provider priced a smaller initial public offering below the expected price range.

docs.lead_paragraph: Aides and allies of the attorney general are quietly and methodically working to bolster the candidacy of Kathleen M. Rice.
